newsitem.title: USA: Ford sees improved 1997 automotive earnings.
newsitem.headline: Ford sees improved 1997 automotive earnings.

text.p: Ford Motor Co Chairman Alex Trotman said the automaker expects improved automotive earnings in 1997, including better results in Europe.
In a statement accompanying Ford's fourth quarter earnings results, Trotman also said the automaker was "on track" to restore profitability in Brazil and Argentina.

"We have a tough business plan in place," Trotman said of the automaker's worldwide strategy. "We expect automotive earnings to improve in 1997, driven by a strong product lineup and company-wide efforts to lower costs."
Ford said Tuesday its 1996 fourth quarter profits jumped about 82 percent to $1.2 billion, or $0.99 per fully diluted share, from $660 million, or $0.48 a share a year earlier.
Excluding extraordinary items, Ford's fourth quarter operating earnings came to $1.10 a share, exceeding the First Call consensus Wall Street analyst estimate of $1.02 a share.
Ford shares were off 1/8 to 32-3/8 in early trading.

"The first priority is to improve near-term automotive results," Trotman said. "Second, we want to continue to grow the earnings of our Financial Services Group. It's clearly one of our undervalued strengths."

Ford's earnings showed improving results in its U.S. automotive operations, which earned $628 million, up from $168 million a year ago, which was hurt by major new product launch costs. But Ford's overseas operations continued to struggle, posting a fourth quarter loss of $238 million versus a year-ago loss of $152 million.

Losses widened in both Europe, where price competition has been brutal, and in South America, where Ford has been forced to launch a virtually new automotive company following the dissolution of its Autolatina joint venture with Volkswagen AG in 1995.
"Europe is tough for everyone, but we expect better results in 1997," Trotman said.
